**Chapter 14**

Rick slammed the portal gun shut, sparks geysering across the battle-scarred garage floor. “All right, Morty! Deadpool! Stand back, unless you want your molecules scattered across meta-space like avant-garde roadkill.”

Morty yanked himself back, eyes darting. “Uhh, Rick? Was it supposed to make that—like, that *metal-grinding* noise? Last time it did that we had two heads each for a week.”

The gun vibrated, lights flickering like a disco inferno in cardiac arrest.

Deadpool twirled his katanas, deadpan. “Please. My digestive system’s scarier after street-meat night. Sure this isn’t just your coffee maker channeling anxiety?”

Rick shot him a glare. “Who wouldn’t weaponize kitchenware to save reality? Don’t answer—” He hoisted the sparking invention, feverish-eyed. “Behold: the Meta-Mangler, trademark pending. This baby’ll cap the meta-humor overflow before we all get retconned.”

Morty edged closer, peering at the thing like it might sprout tentacles. “So…it fixes the narrative leakage, right? Nothing’s gonna—y’know—erase us?”

Deadpool patted Morty’s back. “Worst case, we end up in a ‘Love Boat’ reboot. You ever see what happens to guest stars on that show?”

Rick jabbed a screwdriver into the portal gun’s guts. “Quit gabbing. Morty—fetch the Stabilizer McGuffin. Looks like a blue Slinky cuddling a potato. Top shelf.”

Morty darted off, sidestepping garage litter—(was that a plumbus from Season 2?)—and fished out the device, yelping as it zapped his fingers blue.

Deadpool spread his arms wide. “Marvel meets Adult Swim. Plot holes beware: we’re the spackle.”

Rick snatched the Stabilizer, slamming it home. Everything stilled. The air bristled with static, the fate of a billion punchlines hanging on Rick’s next twitch.

Ultraviolet light pulsed. Instantly, Morty’s eyes went wide. “Uhh, Rick? There’s, like, *smoke* coming out now—”

Rick didn’t look up, sweat streaking his brow. “Quantum exhaust, Morty. Chill. We only die if someone sneezes in four dimensions.” He twisted wires frantically.

Deadpool hopped onto a bench, swinging his legs. “Rick, your quantum exhaust better not be sentient. My hamper’s full.”

A blue arc zipped past, singeing Deadpool’s suit. He cackled. “Closest thing to a spa day I’ve had all year.”

Rick yanked the last wire. The portal gun beeped twice, then spat out a translucent, giggling emoji—which zipped around the garage.

Deadpool lunged at it—*crash*—slamming into a shelf and setting bottles to chime their distress.

Morty hit the floor, wide-eyed. “R-Rick? Are emojis supposed to come out of this?”

Rick smeared oil across his coat, exasperated. “Meta-energy’s unpredictable! Memes, puns, animate cringe, you name it. If there’s a dancing banana, I’m out.”

As if summoned, a sharp, shrill beep cut through—the urgency unmistakable.

Rick scowled at his device. “Don’t like that. Means someone else is hijacking the meta-wavelength. The villain’s cranking up the broadcast. Expect more leakage—fast.”

Deadpool lit up, swords spinning. “Leakier is my comfort zone! Quick, before our brains start hashtagging themselves.”

Rick threw open the garage door. “No time to stall. If we don’t jam the Multinarrative now, we’re all toast—and not the good, buttery kind.”

Morty hesitated, wringing his hands. “Last time you said ‘no stalling’ we got trapped in a musical montage, Rick—”

Deadpool addressed the ceiling as if to the cosmic writers’ room. “If anyone’s rebooting us, can I keep the toy royalties this time?”

Rick, half-listening, grabbed the next component. “Deadpool, stick to stabbing. Morty, stick to not fainting. I’ll stick to improvising.”

The workbench shuddered, thunderous pop. Purple sparks danced across Deadpool’s blades; a half-eaten pizza slid toward the edge.

“Quantum widget—no, the glowy one,” Rick barked, coughing in the haze.

Morty fumbled the part, handing it over. Deadpool, mask rolled to his nose, munched pizza. “Shouldn’t someone call a fire department? Or, like, the TVA?”

Rick seized the widget, sneering. “All Morties panic the same across the Multiverse. And you—” He glared at Deadpool. “If you’re eating radioactive pizza, at least don’t drip on the timeline.”

As he snapped the last circuit, the portal gun glowed, purple and angry. Rick grinned. “Still got it.” 

A *pixelated distortion* shivered through the garage.

Reality bent. Comic-panel borders sliced across shelves. Caption boxes blinked overhead—[NERVOUSNESS INTENSIFIES] above Morty’s head.

Deadpool whistled. “Anyone else feel like a software update’s about to brick us? If Jim Lee’s sketching my abs, I want commission.”

From the ceiling, blocky text flickered: “CHARACTERS SUFFER SEVERE META-OVERLOAD.”

Morty gulped. “Are we—are we supposed to see our narrative glue melting?”

A distorted chuckle echoed—hauntingly familiar, like the villain had always lived between their panels.

The portal gun in Rick’s grip flickered, its shape twisting two-dimensional, leaking impossible color.

Rick locked eyes with Deadpool. “This is it. One wall left.”

Deadpool leaned in toward the audience. “Don’t even blink, folks. It’s about to get seriously weird.”

---

*End of Chapter 14*
